Small Business and Self Employed (SB/SE) and Large Business and International (LB&I) Audit Information Management System (AIMS) / Examination Returns Control System (ERCS) staff.
Table of Contents
Maintaining and Monitoring the Accuracy of the Database
Staff
) This IRM section contains information and procedures for the Audit Management System (AIMS) / Examination Returns Control System staff in operation and support of ERCS.. (
) Purpose: To provide guidance needed by the AIMS/ERCS (A/E) staff for sistency across the business units. (
) Audience: A/E staff in SB/SE, LB&I, including Withholding Exchange and ternational Individual Compliance (WEIIC), and Return Preparer Office Employees include managers, analysts and assistants. (
) Policy Owner: The SB/SE Deputy Director, Examination, who is under the SB/SE Director, Examination. (
) Program Owner: SB/SE Director, Technology Solutions. (
) Primary Stakeholders: LB&I. (

) The A/E staff is an integral part of the ERCS support team. They serve as liaison between the ERCS users and the SB/SE, LB&I and IT employees sponsible for the daily operation and support of the ERCS system. These employees include the Headquarters (HQ) AIMS, ERCS and Summary Time Transmittal System (SETTS) analysts, ERCS system and database ministrators and the ERCS development staff. (

) The A/E staff must be familiar with AIMS and ERCS and have knowledge controlling examinations in SB/SE, Specialty, and LB&I groups, Planning Special Programs (PSP), Centralized Case Processing (CCP), and Services (TS). (

) The A/E manager decides who should perform tasks based upon the ee’s position and grade. Responsibilities of A/E managers include, but are limited to: • Assigning duties. • Monitoring the accuracy of the database. • Creating, maintaining and generating Tableau reports. • Distributing
Statute Tables. • Approving work input on ERCS by the A/E analysts and assistants. (

) Responsibilities of A/E analysts include, but are not limited to: • Adding new ERCS employee records and work schedule proﬁles (WSP). • Processing Business Entitlement Access Request System (BEARS) requests and adding ERCS permission records. • Preparing procedural guidelines and job aids. • Providing formal and informal training. • Advising of ERCS and AIMS program changes and downtime. • Assisting with ERCS login, password and printer issues. • Aiding in the installation of new ERCS session ﬁles. • Elevating unresolved issues to the HQ ERCS analysts. • Maintaining and monitoring the accuracy of the database. • Maintaining the ERCS Address Table. • Updating local ﬁles. • Reviewing audit trails. ) ERCS creates audit trails for selected changes to returns, employee records, and permission records. A special audit trail is also created when users enter taxpayer identiﬁcation number (TIN) or a taxpayer name on ERCS. See IRM
, Security, for more information. IRM
, Audit Trails, has a list of the changes in ERCS that produce an audit trail. (

) There are security checks within ERCS to ensure unauthorized users do not access programs and authorized users are kept within the boundaries of permissions. These checks are performed automatically and silently each a user attempts to access ERCS. The user has no ability to prevent the checks. For more information about permissions in ERCS, see IRM Permissions. (

) The ERCS book in the Virtual Library contains helpful information to resolve problems and answer questions. The following types of information is avail- able: • Manual and Handbooks - this section contains the ERCS user hand- books and the ERCS TRM. The manuals describe the menu options, screens, reports and other relevant information. • Troubleshooting - this section has information on current issues such installing the ERCS session ﬁle and the Invalid SEID error message. • Contacts - this section contains contact information for AIMS/ERCS Staff, Area and Campus Programs, Employee Group Codes, LB&I tacts, and other helpful contact information. (

) Users are granted access to ERCS via a BEARS request. Refer to IRM Security, for detailed information regarding security requirements and assis- tance in determining the appropriate BEARS application needed for ERCS access. (

) The A/E analyst is given read and write permission as an administrator (Admin) user for their assigned Area. Admin is a type of ERCS user reserved for the A/E staff. Admin users may run programs as any type of user (e.g., PSP, group, etc.). Admin permission enables the analyst to research and resolve program, data, or input issues for ERCS users. (

) A/E staff must have an approved BEARS request for their local Area prior to requesting ERCS applications. Access to ERCS applications is requested through the “PROD ANALYST AIMS ERCS STAFF” application on BEARS. Note: ERCS applications enable access to additional options on the Login Menu. The “coordinator” application allows access to the AIMS/ERCS Analyst Menu, the “download” application grants access to the AIMS Download and the “SETTS” application provides access to the SETTS menu. The “assistant” application gives the user access to selected options under the AIMS/ERCS Analyst menu. (

) Users must be aware of the potential for Unauthorized Access of Taxpayer Accounts (UNAX) violations from the use of ERCS. Data from ERCS should accessed only for IRS business purposes. Users should promptly retrieve ERCS reports from printers or fax machines in order to prevent unintentional disclosure. Audit trails are created and subject to review for all user accesses of taxpayer data. For more information about UNAX, see IRM
, IRS authorized Access, Attempted Access or Inspection of Taxpayer Records (UNAX) Program Policy, Guidance, and Requirements. (

Note: It is imperative that local ﬁles are kept up-to-date and should not contain employee personally identiﬁable information (PII) or taxpayer TINs. Local tracking codes follow the same guidelines.

If local project or tracking codes contain the name of the taxpayer for Return Preparer Projects or any other program, the taxpayer’s name must be sanitized on all reports generated and shared outside of PSP. It is recommended that PSP keep a spreadsheet of local codes with taxpayer speciﬁc information and not include taxpayer PII in the ERCS local ﬁles.

SB/SE and LB&I technical employees are required to account for their time in ERCS for each day worked in a cycle. At the end of each reporting cycle the time is extracted from ERCS, validated, and transmitted to the Martinsburg Computing Center (MCC). At MCC, the data goes through a second validation, and is subsequently used in the creation of reports and tables. The term “SETTS” is often used to refer to the entire process from ensuring the time has been input through the receipt of validation results from MCC. The data sent to MCC is used for planning and monitoring activities by technical employees in SB/SE and LB&I. If the time charges on ERCS are corrected after the data has been transmitted to MCC, the corrections are not sent forward and have no impact on the reports and tables that have already been extracted. Everyone, including the examiner applying time, the adminis
(06-27-2022) Processing the SETTS Data

The data sent to MCC is used for planning and monitoring activities by technical employees in SB/SE and LB&I. If the time charges on ERCS are corrected after the data has been transmitted to MCC, the corrections are sent forward and have no impact on the reports and tables that have already been extracted. Everyone, including the examiner applying time, the adminis-

Examination Returns Control System trative support staff inputting or verifying imported time, the manager requisitions with time charges, and the A/E personnel extracting the time, a vital role in ensuring the SETTS data is accurate and timely. (
) AIMS/ERCS staff are responsible for monitoring time input for all groups supported, including LB&I and Specialty, and ensuring all time is complete the last day of the reporting cycle. (
) At the end of each reporting cycle on the designated day of SETTS sion, a member of the A/E staff is responsible for:
Running “Check Employees with Uncharged Time”.
Running “Finished for the Month”.
Creating the SETTS ﬁle.
Appending employee time charges from the previous cycle.
Merging the SETTS ﬁle with forms.txt.
Validating the data.
Correcting validation error.
Re-validating the data if corrections were input.
Transmitting the data to MCC.
Checking the results of the MCC SETTS validation.
Completing the steps to correct and retransmit data, if there are MCC validation errors. (

) Since SETTS cycles can be at four, ﬁve, or six week intervals, users may always be aware when the end of the reporting cycle is near. One way to remind users is by inserting a message in the “Message of the Day” local named “motd”. The last day of each reporting cycle and the corresponding transmission dates are listed in Document
, Examination Division Reporting Codes Booklet. (

) Managers and administrative support staff should be encouraged to run the ERCS “Check Employees with Uncharged Time” report periodically within cycle to ensure all time for their employees has been entered no later than close of business on the last day of the cycle. (

) The “Check Employees with Uncharged Time” report must be run by the employee running SETTS prior to the creation of the SETTS ﬁle. listed on this report with uncharged time for the cycle will be excluded from SETTS ﬁle. If an employee is listed on the report with an In Lieu of Holiday (ILOH) error, it means the employee was not scheduled to work on the and the employee does not have holiday time input on the alternate date program expected the holiday time to be charged. These errors should be searched to see if holiday time was charged on another day. Errors should corrected. If this is the only error for the employee on the report, the ee’s time will still be included in the SETTS ﬁle. Example: If a holiday falls on a Tuesday, but it is the employee’s scheduled day off, the program expects the employee to charge holiday time for Monday. If the employee does not charge holiday time on the an ILOH error will appear on the report. (

) It only takes one day of unreported time or one validation error, either on ERCS or at MCC, to exclude all of the employee’s time charges for the If there is an issue or an error that cannot be resolved by the ﬁnal MCC tion, it is possible to append the employee’s time to the SETTS ﬁle the

) “Finished for the Month” should be run prior to the option to “Create the SETTS_FILE”. This option saves the validated data from the previous cycle a ﬁle named “valid.YYYYMM” where YYYYMM is the cycle date. The option also removes the “forms.txt” ﬁle. (

) During the process of creating, validating and transmitting the time data, several ﬁles are created. It is important to note that corrections are written to intermediate ﬁles and only the ﬁle created by the validation is transmitted to MCC. The following ﬁles are created during the process: • The SETTS_FILE is created when the “Create the SETTS_FILE” is run and the user selects the option “Initial Run”. If the “Initial Run” option is not chosen, new data is appended to any data already in the ﬁle. • The forms.txt ﬁle is created when the option “Merge SETTS_FILE forms.txt” is run. If the forms.txt ﬁle already exists when the option “Merge SETTS_FILE with forms.txt” is run, the data from the SETTS_FILE is appended to any data already in this ﬁle. The ﬁle is deleted when the option “Finished for the Month” is run. Data be updated in this ﬁle when either of the options “Display Error File” “Edit Forms” is run. • The error.txt ﬁle is created when the “Validate Forms” option is run. dation errors are written to this ﬁle. This is the ﬁle displayed when the option “Display Error File” is run. However, when errors are corrected this ﬁle is not updated. The user must re-run “Validate Forms” to this ﬁle. • The valid.txt ﬁle is created when the “Validate Forms” option is run. for employees with no errors is written to this ﬁle. This is the ﬁle mitted to MCC when the option “Transmit Valid SETTS File” is run. (

) The purpose of an Operational Review is to analyze operations and advise groups on inventory controls, case processing, and basic group operations. Typically Assistance Visits are scheduled to address speciﬁc needs of the group. (

) When scheduling an Operational Review an official memo should be drafted and sent to the group manager with a copy to the territory manager at least days in advance. The memo should include the date of the review, whether will be face-to-face or virtual, and list the items that will be reviewed. (

) Once the memo has been issued the “Operational Review Questionnaire” should be sent to the group manager and administrative support assistant a response due date of at least a week prior to the review. This allows the analyst time to incorporate the answers received into their preparation for review. Note: When planning a face-to-face Operational Review the A/E analyst must into consideration that the administrative support assistant/associate may in a POD other than that of the manager. Also, the manager may be a support employee and the A/E analyst will need to verify where the records are being maintained. (
) The A/E analyst will provide written feedback of an Operational Review a reasonable time frame. The suggested time frame is two weeks, but be no later than
days. Note: The following sections pertain to conducting an Operational Review of a or office audit group, however, Operational Reviews are also conducted PSP groups. (
) Knowing the basic group operations enables the analyst to understand the dynamics of the group. Group Operations (
) The basic group operations include the characteristics of the group and the division of responsibilities between the manager, administrative support and technical employees in the group. (

) The characteristics can include items such as the type of cases being (e.g., trust, fraud, general programs, etc.), the type of group (e.g. general program, Special Enforcement Program, training, etc.), the make-up of the group (e.g., trainees, seasoned examiners, new manager, etc.), and if there are any special issues affecting the group. (

) The division of responsibilities in the group can include items such as who runs ERCS inventory reports, inputs technical time, and generates Form Notice of Statute Expiration. Example: Limited users in the group are responsible to input their own technical time and the administrative support assistant inputs any remaining technical time. The group manager is responsible for advising the istrative support assistant of changes needed in employee grades work schedules so employee records and WSPs are updated timely.

) ERCS contains a vast amount of data for returns under examination in and LB&I. Data is transferred to and from ERCS through a number of programs including AIMS. Data is also manually input directly into ERCS users. ERCS data is used to generate reports from the group level to the national level. Therefore, every ERCS user is responsible for ensuring input into ERCS is input accurately and timely. (

) The A/E staff plays a vital role in ensuring the integrity of the ERCS is maintained. In addition to the items checked during an Operational or Assistance Visit, there are other data issues that need to be monitored well as periodic data clean-up initiatives where assistance is needed from A/E staff. There are a number of ERCS reports and programs available to A/E staff to assist in resolving database issues. These reports and include, but are not limited to the following: • AIMS Error Reports • Uploading Reject Reports • Audit Trails • Utility Edit Record and Utility View Record programs • Database Error Report • Maintain Address Table program • Overage Approval Report

) The AIMS Error Reports are a collection of reports generated when AIMS and ERCS data is compared during AIMS to ERCS batch processing. Reports are only created if there is an issue to report. Although some of these reports are available at the end-user level, the A/E analyst can generate them for a par- ticular group, territory, industry, or for the entire area. These reports should be monitored weekly. For information about reports available to end-users and how to work the AIMS Error Reports, refer to the “AIMS Error Reports” and “Miscellaneous AIMS/ERCS Analysts Reports” sections of the IRM
, Reports. (

) Uploading Reject Reports should be worked by the group or function initiating the requests, updates, transfers or closures. Once the rejects have been resolved, the reports should be deleted by the group or function. Uploading Reject Reports that remain on the system for more than a few days may be indication the reports are not being worked or deleted timely or that the users are having problems working the reject. The A/E staff should monitor the reports to ensure the groups or functions are working them timely. Note: Check AIMS Results for AMSOC transfers and closures are only displayed the user who input the transfer or closure on ERCS. It’s recommended that AMSOC rejects be brought to the attention of the A/E manager as they to insure they are promptly resolved. (

) The ERCS audit trails are an invaluable tool that can be used in conjunction with ERCS reports to resolve issues with particular returns. The audit trails are historical records of when returns were added or updated on ERCS, the type of update or change, and the user or program that initiated the action. Refer the Utility Miscellaneous Programs chapter of the ERCS TRM for information about running the Read Audit Trail program and for details about the ERCS audit trails. (

) The Utility Correcting programs enable the A/E staff to correct data on returns that may not be correctable using the end-user menus. It is an option that should be used with extreme caution because the programs do not perform ERCS consistency checks when data is changed. Refer to the Utility Correct- ing Programs chapter of the ERCS TRM for information about this program. (

) The Utility Miscellaneous programs enable the A/E staff to research data on returns that may not be displayed on end-user screens or reports. In addition to the information about the return, the program also displays information about the history record, time charges, recent updates, closing information, pending managerial approval records, and AAC differences between AIMS ERCS. Refer to the Utility Miscellaneous Programs chapter of the ERCS TRM for information about this program. (

) The Database Error Report is used to identify potential errors in the data or in the code lists used to validate the data. It should be run by the A/E staff prior to the end of each cycle to identify potential SETTS errors. It can be run weekly to identify errors introduced after AIMS to ERCS processing or to ensure no new inventory is moved into old AACs after a reorganization. If the user suspects that a code may be incorrectly listed as invalid, the HQ SETTS or HQ ERCS analysts should be contacted. Refer to the “Miscellaneous AIMS/ ERCS Analysts Reports” section of the IRM
, Reports, for information about running and working this report.

) The Address Table contains addresses used in the generation of Form

and in the generation of the Sample Selection sheets. The Maintain Table option is accessed from the AIMS/ERCS Analysts Menu. It enables A/E staff to add, update, and delete addresses, and to save temporary addresses created by end-users to permanent status. When a Form

is generated through ERCS, the corresponding addresses for the sending and receiving groups are displayed on the user’s screen for selection. duplicate addresses and incorrect or obsolete addresses will facilitate the correct address on the documents. Refer to the Login Menu chapter of ERCS TRM for information about running this option. (

) The Overage Approval Report, located on the Utilities Menu, Miscellaneous Programs, is used to monitor updates pending managerial approval. This report is similar to the Work Awaiting Approval report available to users, this report can only be run by PBC and the data on the report is slightly different. If the report is run by

days it lists all returns pending managerial approval. It can also be run by entering a number of days to obtain a list of overage returns pending approval. Refer to the “Miscellaneous AIMS/ERCS Analysts Reports” section of the IRM
, Reports, for information about running and working this report. (
